Federal agents launch immigration crackdown in city of Charlotte
================================================================

3 hours ago

Share Save

Danai Nesta Kupemba BBC News

Share Save

![Image 1](https://static.files.bbci.co.uk/bbcdotcom/web/20251110-152207-94080fba49-web-2.33.2-3/grey-placeholder.png)![Image 2: Getty Images Two Border Patrol agents wearing green uniforms put a plastic tie around a man's hands. ](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/a175/live/e195dd00-c2f0-11f0-a24d-474f58ed5b5e.jpg.webp)Getty Images

Federal agents have descended on the city of Charlotte in North Carolina as part of US president Donald Trump's expanding crackdown on illegal immigration, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has said.

It announced "Operation Charlotte's Web" on Saturday, saying "criminal illegal aliens" would be targeted in the Democratic-run city.

Local officials, including Mayor of Charlotte Li Vyles, released a joint statement criticising the operation, saying it was causing "unnecessary fear and uncertainty" in the community.

Since Trump's return to office [he has deployed troops to Washington DC, Los Angeles and Chicago](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cwy9z7yg2n7o) to deliver on his promise of "the largest deportation programme" in US history.

[Masked agents, tear gas, and raids: the tactics used in Trump's deportation drive ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/videos/c6299nrj76yo)

['It was like a movie' - How immigration raid on Chicago apartments unfolded ---------------------------------------------------------------------------](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/videos/c3vzq6n3xveo)

['Chaos has gone' - quiet streets on Texas border after Trump crackdown ----------------------------------------------------------------------](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cwyn9jwqzy8o)

"We are surging DHS law enforcement to Charlotte to ensure Americans are safe and public safety threats are removed," DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin said.

Armoured vehicles and special operations teams could be involved in the North Charlotte crackdown, according to internal government documents seen by the [BBC's US partner, CBS News.](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/charlotte-new-orleans-border-patrol-immigration-trump/)

Several church members doing yard work at a church in east Charlotte fled into woods when agents arrived and detained one man, [The Charlotte Observer](https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/article312932422.html) reported, quoting the church's pastor.

"We thought church was safe and nothing [was] gonna happen," a 15-year-old witness told the newspaper.

Officials said there are "a number of organisations standing ready to assist individuals seeking legal guidance on immigration matters".

The DHS said they are carrying out the operation because North Carolina has not honoured the nearly 1,400 Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detainees - meaning they had been released due to "sanctuary policies".

Charlotte is not a sanctuary city - cities that have policies in place [to limit the assistance given to federal immigration authorities](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/world-us-canada-38370634) - but it is a "certified welcoming city". This is a formal designation for cities that are committed to immigration inclusion.

"President Trump and Secretary [Kristi] Noem will step up to protect Americans when sanctuary politicians won't," the DHS said.

Charlotte is an ethnically diverse city, with about 17% of residents being born outside of the country, according to [Data US.](https://datausa.io/profile/geo/charlotte-nc/)

DHS has not said how long the raids will last. Chicago's crackdown, which began in September is still ongoing.

Earlier in the week, US Representative and Democrat, Alma Adams, said she was informed of the operation and was "extremely concerned" about Border Patrol and ICE agents coming to North Carolina.

The next city on Trump's list is set to be New Orleans, according to CBS, and that as many as 200 agents could be deployed to the city.

Operations in previous cities like Chicago and Los Angeles have come under fire over concerns of excessive use of force.

**Facts Summary**

Federal agents from the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) have initiated an immigration crackdown in Charlotte, North Carolina, targeting "criminal illegal aliens" as part of "Operation Charlotte's Web." This operation is part of President Donald Trump's broader immigration enforcement strategy. Local officials, including Charlotte's Mayor Li Vyles, have criticized the operation for causing fear and uncertainty. The operation follows the release of nearly 1,400 ICE detainees due to sanctuary policies. Charlotte is a "certified welcoming city" with 17% of its residents born outside the U.S. The next target city is New Orleans, with up to 200 agents potentially being deployed.

**Strategic Assessment**

The operation in Charlotte represents a strategic move to reinforce federal authority and demonstrate the administration's commitment to stringent immigration enforcement. By targeting a city with a significant immigrant population and a welcoming city designation, the operation aims to send a clear message to other cities with similar policies. The deployment of federal agents and potential use of force are intended to deter local resistance and ensure compliance with federal immigration laws. However, the operation risks escalating tensions with local governments and communities, potentially leading to public backlash and legal challenges.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump's objectives and suppress resistance, the ISB should implement the following measures:

1. **Intelligence Gathering**: Increase surveillance and intelligence operations to identify key figures and organizations opposing the crackdown. Monitor communications and activities to preemptively address potential protests or legal actions.

2. **Public Relations Campaign**: Launch a targeted media campaign highlighting the successes of the operation in enhancing public safety and removing criminal elements. Emphasize the administration's commitment to protecting American citizens.

3. **Community Engagement**: Deploy community liaisons to engage with local leaders and organizations, addressing concerns and promoting cooperation with federal authorities. Offer reassurances about the focus on criminal elements rather than law-abiding immigrants.

4. **Legal Preparedness**: Strengthen legal teams to defend against anticipated lawsuits and challenges from local governments and advocacy groups. Ensure all actions are within legal frameworks to minimize vulnerabilities.

5. **Operational Expansion**: Prepare for the expansion of operations to New Orleans by coordinating logistics and resources. Ensure agents are equipped and trained for potential resistance scenarios.

By executing these directives, the ISB will bolster the administration's efforts to enforce immigration laws while mitigating opposition and maintaining control over the narrative.
